A mini recap reel from my recent trip to Lagos, Nigeria. 🇳🇬 Exploring Lagos for six days and eating and drinking my way through the city. There’s something so special about seeing people who look like you and being where you grew up - that feeling is unmatched. 

So glad to have made it home for the second year in a row, not sure when next I’ll be back but I know there are many more adventures for me in the city and I’m looking forward to it all. 

Did you enjoy seeing a glimpse of Lagos through me? Feel free to ask any questions about Lagos and my trip and I’ll be happy to answer. Happy hump day. ❤️

Where did you go in 2022? I can’t believe its the last month of the year already. As I look towards 2023 and make plans, including travel plans, I wanted to share with you some of the things you can do if you’d like to travel more in 2023. I know you have travel goals, and because you follow me, chances are you want to travel more - whether that means visiting more countries, or getting more out of your travel experiences. 

In this video, I share five things you can do now in order to travel more and reach your travel goals in 2023. Now its your turn - score yourself out of five.

1.) Do you have a travel savings account? An account dedicated to saving money for your travels? 1point
2.) Have you written down (not just thought about) the places you want to visit next year and when you might want to go? 1 point.
3.) Have you started researching those places yet? 1 point.
4.) Have you set up flight price alerts on places like google or skyscanner for the places you want to travel to? 1 point.
5.) Do you have a reliable travel insurance to keep you covered while you travel? 1 point.

Let me know if you have any questions about any of the above. And tell me what your score is over 5. Happy December! ❤️

Travel with me to Cartagena, Colombia. 🇨🇴 It’s my first trip of 2023 and I’m feeling so grateful to be back in one of my favorite countries in the world. This place makes me feel alive and at home. The food, the people, the culture, incredible! Already loving it here and glad to be traveling with some amazing women @gojolley. Make sure to follow along to see all that we get up to. 

Have you visited Cartagena, Colombia? Is this a place you’d like to visit? I’ll definitely be sharing lots of tips to help you plan a trip here. Happy Sunday. ❤️

Explore Cartagena, Colombia with me. 🇨🇴 There are only a few cities I’ll never get tired of exploring - and Cartagena is one of them. On first sight, it’s visually stunning, but it’s its depth and soul that really draws you in. There’s street art, cobblestone streets, music at every turn, delicious food and very friendly people. While it’s my second time here, it feels like it’s my first as I’ve fallen in love with this city over again and I’m reminded why I had to come back. 

Some recommendations:
1.) Do a city tour of Cartagena. 
2.) Have lunch at Cande Restaurant. 
3.) Dance with the Palenqueras (the lovely women with the fruit baskets on their head - you’ve got to tip them though). 
4.) Wander around. My favorite photo spots are Carrera 10c, Callejon Anjost and Calle de la Tablada, but really - every corner is gorgeous. 

What’s one word you’d describe this city with?

Black girl joy in Cartagena, Colombia. 🇨🇴 Colombia has a rich and diverse history and you must have seen photos of these beautiful women with their colorful outfits and big smiles. They are called Palenqueras and are originally descendants of West Africa. They came and settled in Colombia, and in order to make ends meet, they started selling fruits and they’ve now become a symbol of Cartagena. 

I loved hearing their stories, dancing with them in the square and basking in the beauty of being in a place as diverse as this. If you go to Cartagena, you can’t miss these women - they are everywhere - just make sure to tip them afterwards. 10,000 Colombian pesos (about $2) is a good place to start.

Who needs a vacation? Well, this is your sign to BOOK IT. ☀️ You deserve it and don’t let fear hold you back from making it happen. 

BUT, I also know somethings may deter you from taking the trip. 

🛫 Maybe you can’t seem to be able to afford it? Make it a priority, create a travel savings account, save monthly, and watch that $$$ build up for your vacation. 

🛫 Maybe you can’t find the time? Create the time. Ask for the time off. Find gaps in your schedule to make it happen. A vacation is good for your mental health too. So make room for it in your life. 

🛫 Don’t know where to go? Go to Colombia haha! But seriously, go somewhere new or revisit an old favorite. Travel doesn’t have to be too far - it can be a nearby city too. 

Who’s taking a vacation this year? Where are you going? Happy Friday. Sending lots of sunshine from Colombia your way. ☀️

I spent an unforgettable afternoon exploring the vibrant and colorful city of Cartagena! From wandering the charming streets and soaking in the rich history, to indulging in some much-needed shopping therapy. 

This city truly knows how to captivate the senses and leave a lasting impression. I can't wait to share more of my adventures in this magical place! Stay tuned for some Cartagena travel tips in the coming days. 🇨🇴

Do not visit Cartagena, Colombia, without knowing these travel tips. [Save + Share]. If you are planning a trip to Cartagena, these are the things you need to know before you go. 

1.) The currency in Colombia can be a bit confusing. So make sure to know it before you go. The currency is the Colombian pesos (COP) and 1 USD is about 4,300 COP. There are bills from 5 mil to 10 mil and up to 100 mil. Mil means thousands so 100 mil is 100,000. Know the currency well to avoid overpaying for stuff. 

2.) Depending on your passport, you may not need a visa to Colombia. US/UK/Canada/EU/Caribbean passport holders don’t need a visa. However, everyone needs to fill out the Check Mig health declaration form before visiting. Just Google Check Mig Colombia for the form. You may not be allowed entry if you don’t have this. 

3.) English is not widely spoken in Cartagena, so make sure to have a Spanish translation app downloaded for use offline. 

4.) Take cash with you, preferably Colombian pesos and make sure you have smaller bills for tips. 

Not mentioned in the video but important: The lines at the airport can be quite long so prepare for longer wait times through customs, especially on entry. You also need a mask at the airport and Colombia still requires either a negative COVID test or proof of vaccination. (As of January 2023)

I hope you found these tips helpful. Let me know in the comments if you did. I’ll be sharing more Cartagena travel tips in the coming days.

Did you know Colombia has such beautiful beaches and islands? 🏝️ Spend a day with me exploring the south of Colombia. I spent a day Island hopping from Cartagena to Isla Baru, the Rosario Islands and Playa Blanca. 

The crystal-clear waters, and breathtaking views of the Caribbean Sea were worth sailing for. These islands are not so far away from Cartagena and are worth the day trip. I also stopped by at the Paue Beach Club for some drinks and I highly recommend checking them out. They even played some afrobeats for us to vibe to. 

Overall, this day was 10/10 and the perfect way to end my 7-day adventure in Colombia. 

TIP: You can do this adventure on a day trip from Cartagena. I rented a private boat but you can get shared boats to Isla Baru. There are lots of tours that offer this. I will share more details and links in a blog post soon. 

What do you think of this vlog style video? Should I do more of it? Let me know in the comments. I hope you’re inspired to add Colombia to your travel list. And let me know if you have any questions.❤️

“Is Colombia even safe?” 🇨🇴 This is a question I’ve received a lot. From my personal experiences, and as someone who has visited Colombia solo and with a group, I can say that I felt completely safe both times. I was very hesitant going solo for the first time in 2019, especially because of how the media painted it, but I challenged my preconceived notions of the place and decided to go for it, while taking necessary precautions of course, and it was the best decision ever. 

During my time in Cartagena, Colombia, I had the opportunity to explore the country and experience the nightlife without any fear or safety concerns. This is not to say that there are no bad people in Colombia, but there are so many good people too.

The people of Colombia were definitely the highlight of my travels. Everywhere I went, I was received with open arms and felt a genuine sense of hospitality. Additionally, my Blackness was celebrated and embraced, and seeing many people who looked like me made me feel at home and welcomed.

This experience reinforced my belief that people are people, no matter where you go in the world. And while some destinations may have a negative reputation in the media, it’s essential to approach new places with an open mind and a willingness to connect with the locals. This can lead to rich and meaningful travel experiences and help to dispel false narratives that often surround certain places.
Thank you to all the people of Colombia for their warmth and kindness towards me. These are experiences I won’t forget in a long time.

What are your thoughts? Share them with me in the comments. Have you ever visited somewhere everyone thought was ‘unsafe?’. Happy February. 🤍

Will you try this bucketlist mud bath experience in Colombia? This place is called Volcan Totumo and the mud is said to have healing properties and good for the skin. I did it... TWICE and I loved it both times - the second time (more recently) even better because I knew exactly what to expect.

What to expect ‼️

1.) You can go from Cartagena to Volcan Totumo - it takes about an hour to get there. There are both private and shared tours that go up there - depending on what your budget is.- 

2.) When you get there, you go up the stairs and are plunged into the mud - you might feel a little scared but it’s okay. You always stay afloat and it is so exciting and relaxing once you’re in there.

3.) You can also get a massage which I recommend - best feeling ever!

4.) Once you are done, you go back down and there is a lake to the left where you can get washed off.
Entry fee is about 30,000 Colombian pesos per person (about $7 USD).

TRAVEL TIP: Make sure to have some spare change as you’ll need to tip people - the person who does your massage, the camera guy (you obviously can’t take your phone or camera with you in there as you’ll be fully immersed in the mud), the lady who washes you off, etc. Everyone wants a tip. I recommend taking at least 50,000 pesos ($10 USD) extra for tips.

Is this an experience you will try?

A photo dump from a day island hopping in the south of Colombia. 🏝️ A core memory I will always cherish. The beach is always better, and this one did not disappoint.

Hello from Cape Town, South Africa. 🇿🇦 After a 14-hour flight from Toronto, I made it down here and I’ve been in love ever since. Cape Town is a city I’ve had on my radar and getting here and experiencing it has exceeded my expectations. The breathtaking scenery, history and culture is so palpable. I’m having the best time and can’t wait to explore everything Cape Town has to offer. For stats, it’s my 52nd country and 5th African country (I need to travel more of Africa❗️) and my 2nd trip of 2023. 

Is Cape Town on your travel list? Have you ever been? I can’t wait to share more from my trip with you and all the tips and recommendations. Stay tuned! 🤍

🚁 One of the highlights of my trip to Cape Town so far has been a helicopter tour of the city. For 20 minutes, we flew above landmarks like Table Mountain, Lions Head, etc to see the view from the top. I truly believe this is the best way to see Cape Town in all of its glory. Cape Town is already stunning but to see it from the top was another level. So glad I got to experience the city this way. 

There are several places you can book a helicopter tour from in Cape Town and the price varies depending on the length of time. I used the company called Cape Town Helicopters and my tour lasted 20 minutes and the timing was perfect.

Is this an experience you’ll be down to do? Yay or nay? 🚁

How stunning is this place? 🤩 I explored the beautiful wine region of Stellenbosch in Cape Town, South Africa and I’m completely in love! I visited three incredible wineries - Thelema, Oldenburg, and Mitre’s Edge - and each one had something unique to offer. But the views at Oldenburg took my breath away! Nestled in the Banghoek Valley, the winery offers panoramic vistas of rolling hills and vineyards that stretch as far as the eye can see. From tasting wine, to enjoying the landscapes, I could not get enough. 

If you’re a wine lover or just like a beautiful stunning natural landscape, you’ll need to add this to your Cape Town bucket list. It would be 100% worth it. Enjoy this highlight reel from my day in Stellenbosch, South Africa. 🇿🇦

I just got back from the most incredible 7 days in Cape Town, South Africa. Cape Town has it all - from its incredible landscapes, to its safaris, beachside restaurants, breathtaking sunsets and super friendly people. With so much to see and do, 7 days was enough to give me a taste and start planning my return. I’m so grateful to have explored this part of Southern Africa. 

Is Cape Town on your travel list? It definitely should be. I’ll be sharing travel tips in the coming days to hopefully inspire you to plan a trip there. From where to eat, things to do, where to stay, etc. I’ve got all the recs so stay tuned!

✨ My African safari experience in Cape Town, South Africa. 🇿🇦 I got to experience my second safari ever in South Africa and it was one for the books. The game drives were epic and the location was stunning and picturesque. I got to see all the big five animals - I guess it was my lucky day. 

If you ever visit Cape Town, I totally recommend taking a Safari day trip to the Aquila Private Game Reserve for a safari experience. This place is about two hours away from Cape Town making it the perfect day trip especially for those with limited time. 

⬇️ Check out some things you need to know. 

1.) This experience can cost between $100 and $250 per person depending on if you choose a shared tour or a private one with just you and your group. I think it is well worth it as safaris can be expensive.
2.) You can book this tour on many booking platforms online and even with your hotel if they offer tours. Just search “Day trip to Aquila game reserve” on Google and you will see a lot of options. 
3.) Make sure to stay hydrated and bring a bottle of water as it does get quite hot.
4.) The drive from Cape Town is about two hours but it will be one of the most scenic rides ever.
5.) Have fun and be patient to spot some of the animals.

Have you ever done a safari before? Would you like to go on one? Also, how many animals can you spot? 🦏🦓🐘🦒🦁

🤯 Woohoo! I faced my fears and paraglided over Cape Town, South Africa. Seeing the breathtaking views of Cape Town from above is an experience I will never forget. The experience took place in Signal Hill, one of the most scenic spots in Cape Town. Although I was initially nervous, I was able to conquer my fears and it was the best decision ever. 

This experience is the stuff bucket lists are made of.
I booked it on @getyourguide - if you’re looking for unique and thrilling adventures like this, make sure to download the app and #makeitunforgettable and #escapethetrap #ad

I had a great time exploring Bo-Kaap, including doing a cooking class to learn Cape Malay dishes. Highly recommend. 

Here’s a mini photo dump of my time in Bo-Kaap. Swipe until the end to see a burst of melanin magic.

👇🏾 I’ve never shared it liked this before (part 1). I recently made it to my 52nd country and wanted to share a bit of the journey with you. From the girl who once dreamed of traveling to world, to actually doing it. It’s been a journey to get here - here’s how I did it. 

🏝️ 2015 - The dream started. I caught the travel bug, but as a Masters student, I didn’t have much money to travel, so this year was for dreaming. I made Pinterest boards, wrote down everywhere I wanted to go, followed those doing the same. And also started saving money - $50, $100, whatever I could save no matter how little. 

👣 2016 - Baby steps. I started traveling affordably. Didn’t care about the aesthetics. I just wanted to see the world. Stayed in ‘humble’ hotels and had a job to support some travel expenses. This gave me a lot of momentum. You have to start somewhere. 2016 was also the year I started my travel blog to share my experiences and tips with the world. 

🏙️2017 - I moved cities and x2 my income. This was major as I now had more disposable income. I earned $0 from my blog but kept putting in the sweat equity. I was traveling and gaining experience and building my network too. I also created a travel savings account and actively saved 15% of my monthly income to fund this dream.

✈️ 2018 - I earned my first $300 from a brand partnership and this eventually became a regular income source for me. I increased my monthly savings to 30% while still saving and investing for the future. 

🏝️ 2019 - I had a breakthrough year, getting promoted at work and earning money consistently from my blog, even getting a sponsored trip to Turkey. This was when things took off. I visited 10 new countries that year also - my most traveled year so far!

🛫 2020 to now, I have now visited 52 countries and can’t wait to see more of the world. With proper planning (mentally and financially and practically) and a desire to see the world, it is possible.

Tomorrow, I’ll share part 2 of this story and advice for those who want to see the world. Is this you? Let me know if this helps and look out for part 2 tomorrow. 🤍

Hola from Mexico. 🇲🇽 It’s my fifth time in this beautiful country and that doesn’t make it any less exciting. 

This time, I’m in the beautiful city of Puerto Vallarta, a coastal destination full of beautiful beaches, history, food and a bubbly night scene. Have you ever been?

Entry requirements + things to know about visiting Mexico in 2023

1.) There are currently no restrictions to travel to or enter Mexico at this time. No tests needed.

2.) US/UK/Canadian passport holders don’t need a visa to Mexico. Likewise if you hold valid visas from the aforementioned countries. 
3.) You’ll be required to fill out the FMM declaration form upon entry. You can find this online or fill it out at the airport. 

4.) The currency in Mexico is the pesos. Bring cash but cards are accepted in some places. 

5.) There is a tipping culture in Mexico. It’s expected. Plan to tip around 10-15% of your bill. 

6.) Get ready to try some authentic tacos 🌮 while at it. And have fun!

Have you ever been to Mexico? If yes, what city have you visited? If not, is this a place on your travel list? Can’t wait to share more of my trip with you. Check out my stories to see more. 🤍 [press/sponsored trip]

✨✈️ Where I traveled to this March. Three countries, three cities, 9875 distance covered. What a month! 

I’m thankful for: 

- the travel experiences I had
- the people and locals I met along the way
- safe travels 
- opportunities that have come from my passion and love for travel 
- support and community.

It was definitely a busy yet exciting travel month for me and looking for a bit of downtime before my next trip in late April. 

⬇️ The destinations and a few recommendations from each of them. 

1.) JAMAICA. 🇯🇲 March started off with a trip to Montego Bay, Jamaica to celebrate my partner’s birthday. Jamaica is always a good idea and I had the best time on my second trip there. I recommend staying at S Hotel Jamaica and doing a Bamboo Rafting experience in Martha Brae. 

2.) DOMINICA. 🇩🇲Only a week after Jamaica, I was off to Dominica to explore a country that I’d always been interested in. This hidden gem country was full of nature and beauty. I recommend adding it to your list. Stay at Rosalie Bay and do a kayaking tour or Soufrière. [press trip]

3.) MEXICO 🇲🇽. March ended with a trip to Mexico for the fifth time but this time around, a different city called Puerto Vallarta. My trip was elevated by a stay at Casa Velas. I recommend doing a food tour while in Puerto Vallarta and walking the malecon. [Press trip]

Which of these countries are on your list? Any travel plans coming up this April? Happy new month! 🤍

✨ Rating my Q1 2023 (first quarter) travels over 10. I have to admit, I’ve thoroughly enjoyed the places I’ve visited so far this year. Here are some reasons for my ratings. 

1.) Cartagena, Colombia 🇨🇴- a solid 9. This place has it all. From the good food to the friendly people. It’s near perfect. 

2.) Cape Town, South Africa - 9.5/10 🇿🇦- the best place I have visited so far this year. Cape Town is a dream. A travelers dream and I already know I’ll visit again.

Travel can be an exciting adventure, but let’s face it, it’s not always smooth sailing. Delayed luggage, missing documents, flight cancellations - these unexpected mishaps can put a damper on your trip. But don’t worry, how you handle these situations can make all the difference. 

Here are some tips to help you stay calm and prepared if you ever find yourself facing these common travel hiccups:

1.) Lost luggage - report it immediately and consider investing in a luggage tracker like an Airtag. Always pack a change of clothes and essentials in your carry-on, and keep receipts for any necessary purchases. Airlines will often reimburse you.

2.) Losing your passport or ID - contact your embassy right away and get a temporary travel document. Also, have digital copies of your passport on your phone or cloud storage for easy access.

3.) Flight cancellations - unfortunately, this is out of your control, but you may be able to get compensated. Call the airline immediately and ask to be put on standby for a same-day flight. If you are traveling for an important event like a wedding or birthday or any other major milestone that cannot be missed, always travel at least a day or two earlier to give room for situations like this. 

4.) Damaged luggage - take a picture of any damage as soon as you notice it, and also take a picture of your luggage before checking it in. The airline is responsible for any significant wear and tear.

5.) Losing your wallet with your cards - call your bank to cancel your cards immediately and carry extra cash. Travel with two cards if you can and keep them in separate places, and consider using Apple Pay for added convenience.

Finally, It’s always a good idea to have travel insurance in case of emergencies, and remember to stay calm and try to enjoy your trip regardless. 

Have you ever experienced any of these mishaps on your travels? Share your story in the comments below! If you found this helpful, don’t forget to share with others too! 🤍

Traveling the world is a dream for many, but often we let obstacles hold us back. For me, those obstacles included 1.) having a Nigerian passport, 2.) a limited budget, 3.) a full-time 9-5 job, 4.) the uncertainties of being a black traveler (I wouldn’t change this for anything!), and 5.) not always having a travel companion. But instead of letting these challenges stop me, I found ways to overcome them and explore over 50 countries.

I diligently applied for visas, traveled within my means, embraced remote work, used weekends and holidays to my advantage, and discovered the beauty of solo travel. And despite some people telling me that travel wasn’t for me or that I wouldn’t be accepted in certain places, I refused to let their opinions hold me back.

So if you’re dreaming of seeing the world but feel like it’s not possible, know that with determination and a little creativity, anything is possible. Life is too short to not explore the beauty this world has to offer.

Postcards from Tokyo, Japan 🇯🇵

You’ll want to see this if Japan is on your travel bucket list. Sharing exactly how I prepared for my epic trip to Japan this year. Traveling to Japan for the second time was a lot different from the first. A lot of things have changed about traveling to Japan especially in 2023. Check out this video to see how I prepared for my trip. [Save + Share] 

1.) I got the JR pass in advance. 
2.) I needed to get a booster shot as it was required to have 3 shots or a negative test.
3.) I got some travel essentials for Japan, including this handy coin bag. I wish I took a small bag with me to keep my trash in as there are hardly any trash cans in Japan.
4.) I exchanged yen at a local currency exchange in Toronto called Continental Exchange. You can exchange yen when you get to Japan too but always good to get some in advance to get you started. 
5.) I learned key Japanese phrases but so important to download that Google translate app and use the camera feature especially for menus. The language barrier in Japan is quite steep.
6.) I got a data package off an app called Airalo. I got the 20GB package but that was an overkill as I didn’t need that much data. I think 10GB should be enough for a 7-10 day trip.
7.) Important: I filled out the customs forms on the Visit Japan app and it helped me cut the lines at the airport.

Let me know in the comments if this helps. Is Japan on your list? Be sure to save and share for more travel tips like this. Happy Sunday. 🤍

Add this place to your Tokyo bucketlist! 🤯 TeamLab’s Planet Tokyo is an immersive art exhibition that will transport you to another universe. As soon as I walked in and saw the exhibitions, I was completely mindblown. The combination of digital technology and art creates a surreal experience that you won’t find anywhere else. 

If you’re heading to Tokyo, I highly recommend visiting TeamLab’s Planet Tokyo. Here are some important tips before you go:

1.) Prepare to remove your shoes throughout the whole experience.
2.) Wear knee-length clothes or clothes you can fold up, as some areas require walking in water.
3.) Wear shorts underneath if you’re wearing a skirt or dress, as some rooms are mirrored.
4.) Allow at least 2-3 hours to explore all the exhibitions.
5.) Book your tickets in advance. They cost about 3200 yen for adults.
6.) If possible, go in the morning around 9am to beat the crowd.

This experience is absolutely worth it and even better in person. Is this a place you’ll love to visit? Let me know your thoughts in the comments below. 👇🏾

A guide to long haul flights. ✈️ I’ve been taking a lot of long haul flights lately, 13 hours to Cape Town, South Africa, 14 hours to Japan, my most recent trip. 

As someone who is not new to the long haul flight game, having a few essentials can make a world of difference. 

Watch this video to see my top 7 must-haves when taking a long-haul flight. And the best part, all items can be found on Amazon. 🤩

Items mentioned:

1.) Anker power bank that attaches to the back of your phone and can also serve as a prop.
2.) Airfly Bluetooth so you can use your Airpods or headphones instead of the ones provided by the airlines which tend to be of lower quality.
3.) Compression socks to prevent your feet from swelling. 
4.) TRTL pillow - portable and efficient neck pillow
5.) Bring my own entertainment - books, tv shows downloaded offline. 
6.) 3 in 1 charger to charge all your devices at once. 
7.) Hydrating skincare - I love summer friday’s jetlag mask. 

What are some of your must-have inflight essentials? Did you find this helpful? Let me know in the comments!

We took over the streets of Kyoto, Japan! 😍 Taking over Japan with my @gojolley squad has been such a delight. When putting this trip together, I wanted us to have the best of both worlds - city escapes in Tokyo and cultural experiences in Kyoto, and we definitely did. My pride and joy is to help people see a place seamlessly and to help them immerse in a new experience.

Who will you travel to Japan with? Tag your travel squad below.

Japan is one of the most culturally unique and fascinating destinations I’ve been to. It’s like a whole new world. Here are some of the interesting things I found out about Japan while exploring the Land of the Rising Sun. 

1.) The roads are very clean but there are hardly any bins.
2.) Taxi drivers must always wear a black suit.
3.) The bathrooms are very high tech and cool. 
4.) Japanese eat rice alot, I even tried a rice burger.
5.) The trains are always very quiet. Unlike what I am used to.
6.) Tipping is not necessary, its not expected and in some instances, frowned upon. 

Honorable mention: Thé fact that there are so many vending machines all around and there’s a vending machine for everything - including getting a romantic date - yes, this is real. 😅 I just might make a part 2 because there’s so much more!

But which of these do you find the most interesting? Let me know in the comments below. 👇🏾

Exploring what I believe to be the most beautiful temple in Japan 🇯🇵. Kinkaku-ji, also called the Golden Pavilion is a UNESCO World Heritage site and a must-visit spot in Kyoto, Japan. The temple has stunning architecture and its top two floors are completely covered in real gold.

This is one of my favorite spots in Japan and I recommend adding it to your list. It cost about 500 yen to enter and honestly, it'll take your breath away.

Swipe left for some photos from Kinkaku-ji. Let me know what you think about this place. 🤍

Kyoto is my favorite city in Japan, and although Tokyo often steals the spotlight, this beautiful city in Western Japan is worth a spot on your bucket list.  If you’re seeking a more cultural and slow-paced experience, Kyoto is the perfect destination to escape the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. With just a two-hour bullet train ride from Tokyo, you can visit Kyoto for a day or, better yet, spend three days or more exploring the city’s wonders.

After having visited Kyoto twice, I highly recommend the following five activities:

1.) Visit the Kinkaku-ji temple. 
2.) Explore the Arashiyama Bamboo Forest.
3.) Experience Fushimi Inari, the most popular attraction in Japan.
4.) Try new food at Nishiki Market (one of my favorite experiences in Kyoto).
5.) indulge in a Japanese tea ceremony.

Do you prefer a city vibe like Tokyo or a more cultural, slow paced city like Kyoto? Let me know what you think. And make sure to save this post for later. I’ll share the best things to do in Tokyo in the next few days. Happy Sunday. 🤍

A guide to Tokyo, Japan 🇯🇵. As promised, here are some of my recommendations of the things to do in Tokyo. Tokyo has a lot to offer for every kind of traveler, but if you only have 3 or 4 days in Tokyo, here are some things to do.

1.) Visit the sensoji temple.
2.) Stop by at Tsukiji Fish Market: A foodie’s paradise  where you can try different Japanese street food. 
3.) You can’t miss Shibuya Sky: From here you can see Tokyo’s impressive skyline. Book this well in advance.
4.) Experience teamLab: An impressive art exhibition. Also, book this in advance.
5.) If you are an anime lover, the neighborhood of Akihabara is the place to be.
6.) Experience the world’s busiest pedestrian crossing at Shibuya crossing. As many as 3,000 people cross per time.

General Tokyo tips. 
1.) If you can, fly into Haneda Airport, not Narita, as it is much closer to the city and you can save time and money.
2.) Bring cash.
3.) Bring a coin bag. 
4.) Public trash cans are scarce, so bring a small paper bag with you.
5.) Silence is golden. Being quiet in public spaces is expected.

Is Tokyo on your list? Let me know if you found this post helpful. 🤍

Japan is a foodie’s paradise and as someone who is quite the picky eater and sticks to what she knows, my palette was very much stretched. I’m so glad I was able to step out of my comfort zone and try new food. 

Here’s everything I ate. [save for your own foodie adventures in Japan]

1.) Sushi. 
2.) Ramen
3.) Gyoza (Japanese dumplings)
4.) Japanese BBQ 
5.) Takoyaki (Octopus balls)
6.) Mochi (Rice cakes)
7.) Yakitori (Grilled chicken skewers)
8.) Rice burgers

Which of these Japanese foods have you ever tried? Let me know if you enjoyed this video. Happy Friday y’all. 🤍

A guide to 7 days in Japan 🇯🇵 Let’s be honest, not everyone has 2 weeks to spend in Japan, so if you only have 7 days to spare, that’s a good amount of time to experience the beauty and culture that Japan has to offer. 

I spent 7 days exploring Tokyo and Kyoto. This was the perfect blend of city life in Tokyo and cultural escapes in Kyoto. 

Itinerary [full travel guide now on my blog] 🔗

Day 1 - Arrivals in Tokyo (you can choose between Tokyo Narita Airport or Haneda airport. Haneda is closer to the city so you’ll spend less on transportation. 

Day 2 - Explore Tokyo on a full day tour. Start off at Sensoji temple and then Tsukiji Fish Market and then head to Team Labs Planet and end the day at Shibuya Sky. 

Day 3 - Explore a bit more of Tokyo in the morning. Visit Tokyo Towers and Meiji Jingu Shrine. In the afternoon, catch a bullet train to Kyoto. 

Day 4. Explore Kyoto. A Japanese tea ceremony and Kimono Rental experience. Take the rest of the day off. 

Day 5 - More Kyoto. Visit Fushimi Inari, Kiyomizu Temple & Arashiyama Bamboo Forest. 

Day 6 - Explore Kyoto in the morning. Head over to Nishiki Market. In the afternoon, catch a train back to Tokyo. Spend the evening at Akhihabara. 

Day 7 - Departure. 

Check out my blog for a full travel guide now available with all the places I stayed, ate and all my travel tips and recommendations for Japan. I hope you enjoyed the Japan travel series. Thank you for following along as always. Happy Sunday. 🤍

Everything you should know about visiting Phi Phi Islands. ⬇️ Add this place to your bucket list. This is Phi Phi Islands in Thailand. You’ve probably seen picturesque photos online and believe me, it’s even more magical in person. 🤩

Phi Phi Islands is the perfect day trip from Phuket. It’s only an hour away by speedboat. There are several tour companies that go there and it typically costs about $80-$100 for a shared tour that includes several island stops like Khai Island, Monkey Beach, Bamboo Island and even Maya Bay. 

How to book:
1.) I booked my tour on Klook. I love using Klook for my South East Asia adventures. Let me know in the comments if you want a discount code and I’ll send you one. A shared tour costs about $80 and that includes hotel pick up and drop off. 

2.) When you get to Koh Phi Phi, you can rent a long tail boat (traditional Thailand wooden boat) for an hour or more. Prices start at 1000 baht depending on how you negotiate. I definitely recommend a wooden boat tour for an authentic Thailand experience. 

3.) Bring cash with you as you won’t find a lot of ATMs on the island. 

Overall, I definitely recommend a visit to Phi Phi Islands. It’s absolutely breathtaking. 

Have you ever visited Phi Phi Islands? Is this a place you’ll want to go to? Let me know what you think. 🤍

Postcards from Bangkok, Thailand. 🇹🇭 I spent a day exploring the most visited city in the world - Bangkok, Thailand. 

Did you know that every year, more than 8 million tourists visit Bangkok? This city is magical and there’s just so much to do there. 

Here are my top recommendations for a 3-4 day Bangkok visit. 
1.) Visit Wat Pho to see the reclining Buddha
2.) Visit Wat Arun
3.) Visit Grand Palace 
4.) Ride the sky train
5.) Do a food tour on a Tuk Tuk 
6.) Visit a floating market 
7.) Eat out of China town 
8.) Have a Thai massage 

Swipe to see some of my favorite photos from my visit to the Grand Palace in Bangkok. The details are stunning. 🤍

[ Save + Share ] This is a guide to your first trip to Thailand. 🇹🇭 Anyone have Thailand on their bucketlist? It’s time to make it happen. 

Thailand is one of the most affordable countries I’ve visited - the flight price might be steep, but things get better when you land. 🙌🏾

See a mini guide below for a 7-day trip, especially if it is your first time. 

• Cities to cover - Bangkok (3 days) and Phuket (4 days)
• STAY: Bangkok - Valia Bangkok Hotel. Phuket - Amatara Resort (@amatararesort)

• Best time to visit: November to April for the best and sunniest weather ☀️ However, note that it will be VERY sunny. Going in May meant it was still sunny but there were mornings of light showers. Even when it rained, it was still humid. 

• Cash or card? Both! But carry cash for tipping, street food and when you go to more remote islands as ATMs are few and far between. 

• Things to do? 
Phuket - Day trip to Phi Phi Islands, City tour of Phuket including the Big Buddha, Visit an ethical elephant sanctuary, ATV riding and zip lining adventures. 

Bangkok - Temple hop through Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Wat Pho. Do a Tuk Tuk street food tour, Go experience a floating market, Get a Thai massage. Really so much to do in Bangkok. 

• General tips - Bring a scarf or two for temples. Don’t book all your tours in advance - you’ll find it to be more affordable when you get here. Prepare for the heat. Light and breathable fabrics ONLY. Most importantly, enjoy. 🤍

Was this helpful? Yay or Nay in the comments if a visit to Thailand is in your future plans! ✈️

Where to stay in the Maldives. 🏝️ Maldives is paradise on earth but it can be a bit confusing figuring out where to stay on your trip. I honestly felt slightly overwhelmed trying to choose my ideal hotel in the Maldives. With more than 1,000 islands that look quite similar, where do you stay? 

Ultimately, where you choose to stay depends on a number of factors, including cost, resort vibe and time of travel. Low season is May to November and hotel prices are *slightly* lower. On my trip to Maldives, I chose the island of @kuramathiisland . 

Not only is the resort absolutely stunning, it is also just a 20-minute seaplane ride away from the Male International Airport. There are lots of activities to choose from, or you can just completely unplug and do nothing while soaking up the surrounding views. (Press stay). 

Be sure to do your research, compare the different islands before choosing where to stay. And if you just want my recommendation, I’ll say @kuramathiisland all the way. It’s the perfect island getaway. 🏝️

Sharing ten things you need to know before you go to Thailand. Watch this video for all the tips and feel free to hold the screen to read. Save and share for your future trip. 📌

Tips mentioned ⬇️

1.) Best time to visit is November and April for the best weather
2.) Don’t book all your activities in advance, you will find it to be a lot cheaper when you get there
3.) If you want to book in advance, use an app called Klook

4.)Thailand is very hot and humid so light breezy outfits are a must
5.) Make sure to have cash, as you can’t pay by card ,at a lot of places and most businesses will charge you 2% per transaction.
6.) Download the app Grab which is their version of Uber. Food and transportation are so much cheaper with it.

7.) Pack scarves and dress decently when visiting temples
8.) If you have a UK/US/Canada passport, you do not need a visa. Make sure to check visa requirements before you go.
9.) Most people speak English but still advisable to have a translation app. l love Google translate.
10.) Pack properly - sunscreen, bug spray are a must.

I hope this helps. Comment below ‘yay’ or ‘nay’ if Thailand is on your travel list. Thanks for watching. 🤍

[save + share] Your Bali Itinerary sorted. 📌 I spent a little over a week in Bali and had the most incredible time. It was the perfect mix of immersing in the culture and indulging in the free-spiritedness of Bali.

Here’s an itinerary on how to spend a week (and a few days more if you have more time to spare) in Bali. This itinerary has been used by many, and we call it the Jessica Ufuoma Bali Itinerary. If you know, you know. 😋

1.) Day one - Arrivals
2.) Day two - Ease your way into Bali with a floating breakfast at Tlaga Singha in the morning. An evening cooking class at Paon Bali.
3.) Day three - Ubud adventures. Bright and early start at the Real Bali Swing and the Rice terrace at Tegallalang.
4.) Day four - Day trip to Northern Bali. See places like Wanagiri Hidden Hills, Handara Gates, Ulun Danu Temple and Banyumala Twin Waterfalls (preferably in that order - you want to end your very busy day with a dip in the pool at the waterfall. the best!)
5.) Day five - Take a break and indulge in a floating bath session and Balinese massage. Catch the epic sunset at Jimbaran Bay.
6.) Day six - A day trip to the islands of Nusa Penida
7.) Day seven - Jewelry-making class and an afternoon at the Ubud art market for some souvenirs and shopping
8.) Day eight - Departure time

Optional if you have more time to spare - Gate of Heaven and Tirta Gangga on day 8 and then departure on day 9.

Let me know in the comments if you found this helpful. Who’s feeling inspired to travel to Bali? Happy Sunday y’all!

📌 STORYTIME: I recently had the most incredible 8 days in Bali, Indonesia and I’ve shared many highlights with you. But my Bali story won’t be complete without sharing this observation with you. 

In 2019 when I first traveled to Bali, I had my Nigerian passport. I had planned my first group trip to Bali but didn’t realize how hectic the visa application was going to be. I thought it was going to be a regular visa application but ended up paying about $850 to get my visa. $850 is a lot for a visa but I had already booked my flight for more than $2000 so at this point there was no turning back. Anyway my visa got approved and I went to Bali. I had a good time but was definitely salty that I had to pay that much for a visa just because of the color of my passport. (There’s also the part where not everyone can afford these visa fees.)

Fast forward to 2023, visiting the same country but now with a new Canadian passport. I didn’t have to do anything prior which was a huge mental weight off my shoulders. Upon arriving Bali, I got a visa on arrival which cost only $35 and the process was as easy as A B C. What changed? The color of my passport. It made such a big difference and if I hadn’t experienced the former, I wouldn’t have appreciated the ease of the latter. 

My point today is to use my platform to share the realities of passport privilege and how unfair it is that people are maginalized due to the color of their passport, which for most people they didn’t get to choose. As someone who has experienced both sides, I can tell you this is a real and painful struggle people face. And this is not just about just leisure travel but also access - access to better healthcare, education, etc. And maybe, just maybe if we speak up more about passport privilege, things can change or at least improve. 

Thanks for reading. Feel free to share your thoughts in the comment. Happy Friday. 🤍

Enjoying the outdoors of Michigan was a delight. Did you know that Michigan is called ‘The Great Lakes State’? 

Michigan is surrounded by four of the five Great Lakes: Lake Superior, Lake Michigan, Lake Huron and Lake Erie. These lakes comprise the largest group of freshwater lakes on Earth, and Michigan is the only state that touches four of them. Incredible, right?

Kayaking on the river was one of the highlights of my trip to Michigan. It was the perfect day to get on the water and enjoy the beautiful scenery. I kayaked on the Saginaw River and absolutely enjoyed it. Save this activity for your next Michigan adventure. #ad @expedia @puremichigan

It’s been exactly a year since I became a Canadian citizen with new found passport privileges. Prior to then, I held a passport that not only made traveling the world more challenging, but very costly. I sat down the other day to do the math on how much I would have spent if I still needed to apply for visas to visit all the places I’ve gone to so far. In total, it is about $2,404 roughly. 

Ultimately, that is $2,404 dollars back in my pocket that can be invested, spent on more travel or saved. 

As always, sharing this to continue to spread awareness of passport privilege and hope to continue using my platform to do so. Let me know your thoughts. ❤️

Love these moments in Peru. I recommend doing a tour of the Sacred Valley to have an experience like this. 🤍

Add these incredibly stunning places to your list ASAP. 😍 Peru is full of awesome landscapes and natural beauty but here are three of my favorite places in Peru that made me go, “WOW”. 

1.) Maras Salt Mines - Located in the Sacred Valley of the Incas, these salt pans have been a major source of salt extraction since the pre-Inca era. In a nutshell, this place is stunning. You can experience it when you do a classic Sacred Valley tour while in Cusco, Peru. 
2.) Rainbow mountain, also called Vinicunca is a sight for sore eyes. Admittedly, getting up there is a challenge due to the altitude BUT upon getting there, the reward is worth it. It’s not everyday you see a rainbow-colored mountain. 
3.) Machu Picchu needs no introduction. One of the most beautiful places on earth, it’s no wonder it is a World Wonder. You’ve got to see this place in person. 

Which of these three places caught your eye? I hope you’re feeling inspired to add Peru to your bucketlist. It’s perfect for you if you’re looking for a unique cultural experience. There’s so much to see in the world - let’s explore while we can. 🤍🌎

I started sharing my travel experiences because I wanted to see more of us travel the world. The year was 2015 and I did a gruesome four-day hike of Machu Picchu, Peru. Upon getting to the mountain, the tour group celebrated this incredible milestone but then I looked around and there was absolutely no one who looked like me seeing this beautiful world wonder like I was. 

I traveled back home and as soon as my luggage hit the ground, I researched how to start a blog, watched countless YouTube videos to set up my first website, created an Instagram page, and the rest is history. 

Don’t let anything or anyone stop you from seeing the world. I’m proof that we absolutely can. 🤍

Have you ever seen these colorful mountains online? Chances are, you have. It is called Rainbow Mountain - Vinicunca Mountain in Peru and it is one of the most beautiful sites I have ever seen in all of my travels. The various colors are a result of different minerals, such as iron, copper, and sulfur, oxidizing and interacting with the environment over time. 

It’s the perfect day trip from Cusco, BUT getting here is not a walk in the park. At more than 17,000ft above sea level, the altitude is not a joke. But if I can do it with little to no hiking interest in me, so can you. 

Just be prepared as much as you can by:
1.) Staying hydrated 
2.) Chewing loads of coca leaves 
3.) Pacing yourself
4.) Having a good tour guide to keep you on track and motivate you. 

Is this a hike you will do? And are you team hike 💪🏾 or team horse 🐴 or both? (Half hike, half horse like I did.) Let me know in the comments! Happy Monday y’all. 🤍

A solo travel hack? Hire a local and knowledgeable tour guide. I’ve done this for years, especially when going to places where I don’t speak the local language and I need that extra bit of help navigating. It’s also a plus when they double as a private driver and tour guide.

On my recent solo trip to Kenya, I did this as well and that meant I felt safe navigating the city with a local and didn’t have to figure anything out by myself.

But the question is. HOW? How do you find a good AND reliable driver abroad?

1.) I check places like Viator and Getyourguide. I also search on Facebook groups as well. I also always keep the contacts of people I meet as I travel in case I revisit the country.
2.) How to vet them? If they have reviews, that’s a good place to start. Talk to them before the trip, preferably on the phone. 
3.) Don’t fully commit until you’ve met them in public. Start with one tour and if things go well, you can do more tours with them.
4.) As a rule, and just because I have a public profile, I never contact them with my Instagram account as I don’t want them to have too much info about me before they even meet me.
5.) Always use your intuition. More times than not, it is right. Trust it. Look out for signs of desperation, exaggeration and general red flags. 

Do you use tour guides when you travel solo? Is this a hack you can get behind? Let me know if you have any questions on this. Happy Friday. 🤍

👇🏾And here’s some more Ibiza tips to know before your trip. 

1.) There’s no Uber in Ibiza so you’ll have to use taxis to move around. You can also rent a car. Taxis take cards too. 

2.) You’d rarely need any cash as most places accept card payments. 

3.) If you want to party, you’ll need to go between May and October as this is when all the events happen. The island pretty much shorts down after October. 

4.) Book your event tickets in advance. They sell out quickly. I used clubtickets.com to book. 

Overall, loved Ibiza and definitely recommend visiting next summer. 👍🏽 Save this for later and let me know what you think. 🤍

Ready for the ultimate European adventure? Now THIS is how to plan an epic trip to Europe! 🌎✈️

I recently spent 7 days exploring Spain and Portugal and visit Europe every year. Here are some of my tips to help you plan your own epic European adventure.

EUROPE TRAVEL TIPS ⬇️

1.) First, decide where you want to go and how much you can spend. Europe has tons of countries, so choose wisely.

2.) Plan your route logically. For example, start in the north, like the Netherlands, then head south to France and Italy. Think about cool combos like Spain and Portugal, Italy and Greece, or Switzerland and Austria.

3.) Use helpful apps like City Mapper and Rome2Rio to figure out your transportation options.

4.) Pick the right time to go. May and September are great because there are fewer crowds, decent weather, and you can save some money on places to stay.

5.) If you can, hop on a train. The Eurail app is super handy for planning train trips.

6.) Time your trip well. With 7 days, aim for 2 cities. With 10 days, go for 3. This way, you won’t rush through everything.

Who has Europe in their future travel plans? Hope these tips help you make it unforgettable!” 🌍🗺️✈️

How to REALLY start traveling the world. 🌎 ✈️

1.) Set clear travel goals and priorities. Don’t be afraid to start small. Travel locally and then expand from there. 
2.) Create a travel budget and start saving money. Even better if you save a % of your income monthly in a high interest savings account. 
3.) Cut unnecessary expenses to fund your travels. Priorities. 
4.) Or better yet, increase your income by accepting higher paying jobs or getting a side job. 
5.) Research and plan your destinations. Use blogs and reputable travel sites and for research. 
6.) Decide on the duration of your trips. The longer your trip, the more expensive. 
7.) Apply for necessary visas and travel documents.
8.) Book flights and accommodations in advance. I recommend three to six months. 
9.) Pack light and efficiently. This saves you time and money. 
10.) Consider travel insurance for peace of mind.
11.) Learn about local customs and culture. 
12.) Be open to meeting new people and trying new things.
13.) Embrace spontaneity but have a rough itinerary.
14.) Learn from your experiences and adapt your plans as needed.
15.) Enjoy the journey and create lasting memories. Don’t forget to capture the moments. 📷

🌴☀️ MALDIVES TRAVEL GUIDE ⬇️

Where to stay 🏡 
There are so many accommodation options in the Maldives for every budget. If you want to have the overwater villa experience, I recommend @kuramathiisland the one I stayed at. A stunning secluded island with the most dreamy blue water.

Best time to go ⏰ 
For the most perfect sunshine weather, go between November and April when the sun is shining and there is no rain. I went in May and the weather was still very good, but there was little rain. 💦

Who to go with 👫
Contrary to popular opinion, Maldives can be enjoyed by friends, solo, lovers, etc. So go with whoever you want to go with. 

How to get there ✈️
you’re anywhere in Asia, you’ll mostly find direct flights to the Maldives. The UK, UAE also have direct flights but from other parts of the world, you may need to have a connecting flight to get there. I recommend going if you’re already visiting Asia. You may also need to get a speedboat or seaplane to your resort. They can arrange this for you. 

Things to do 🤿
Snorkeling, island hopping, scuba diving, jetsking, etc. Mostly water activities. Or you could just do nothing. The Maldives is the ultimate do-nothing relaxation holiday.

Who’s dreaming up a Maldives vacation next year? Save this for your future Maldives getaway and share this with anyone you want to go with. 🌴

Matching a destination to the timing allows you to have the best experience. For example, you may have Morocco on your bucketlist but January isn’t the best time to go because it’s cold 🥶. You may have Thailand on your list but August may not be the best time because of the Monsoon season. 

This is not a rule book, instead, it’s a guide so choose what works best for you, your schedule and your budget. 

These are the factors:

1.) Great weather 
2.) Important event in the country - for example a festival in Brazil or the Northern Lights in Iceland
3.) Overall great value for money.

And of course my own personal experiences in these places.

⬇️ My Mini London Travel Guide 🇬🇧 // For my last trip in 2023, I made my way to London, UK for the very first time. I typically do a tropical holiday for Christmas but wanted to switch it up and I’m glad I did. 

I really LOVED London. And know I’ll be going back. Here’s my mini London guide, where I stayed, what I did and general advice, especially for first timers like myself. 

🏨 Where I stayed - Vintry and Mercer, a 5-star boutique hotel property with amazing service across the board. Loved all the charming decor and the afternoon tea experience there was top-notch. 

🎯 What I did - As it was my last trip of the year, I planned very minimal activities. I just wanted a slower trip with a few landmarks. I got to do the classic afternoon tea, did a city tour of London where I saw places like Trafalgar Square, the Buckingham palace, etc. 

🐾 Places I visited - Oxford street, Regent Street for the most beautiful Christmas decor, Covent Garden (loved it), Hyde Park Winter Wonderland, Big Ben, London Eye, @arsenal’s Emirates Stadium (very niche activity but the highlight of my trip). 

🥘 Restaurants I ate at and loved - Akara London (Nigerian/West African), Coco Grill (Mediterranean), Figo Restaurant (Italian), The Lampery (British), Gura Gura (Asian)

London tips/ general advice I picked up ⬇️
1.) You do not need cash for anything. I even tipped my tour guide virtually. He had a little POS with him LOL. 
2.) You can use your credit card for the tube transportation. 
3.) Uber works well (this was our primary transportation mode although more expensive) BUT sometimes it takes so long to find a ride. Sometimes we waited 20 minutes. 🫠
4.) London itself can get quite $$$, but if you venture out of the city, I hear it could be cheaper. We did spend all our time in London as we were there for a short time. 
5.) The London weather - depending on when you go, prepare for rain and clouds but it’s honestly part of the city’s vibe and I didn’t mind that at all. 

Overall, I totally enjoyed my first London experience and can’t wait to be back. Did you follow along? Let me know if you enjoyed the London series. Thanks for following along as always. 🤍

An overdue life update 🤍 

Last year, In November of 2022, I made the difficult decision to leave the corporate life, a six-figure salary and become my own boss. As someone whose identity was very much tied to being a corporate girlie and climbing the corporate ladder, this was tough.

But I knew I wanted more out of life. It was no longer just about money. It was about time. Time is our most prized possession and I wanted to spend my days doing what I love, building my legacy and going where I wanted to go. 

So I left. And didn’t look back. 

What happened next? Many great things. 
A few of them: Tripling my old salary, becoming an ambassador for a major travel brand, becoming happier, healthier, more confident
Leading an amazing team of 7 women

But most importantly, building what will last and writing my own script. 🤍

I wanted more time but ironically, 2023 has been my most abundant year yet. Opportunities have flown to me with ease, and I am the girl of my dreams now. 

Going into 2024 the most inspired I have ever felt. Ready to keep on building my legacy, my story, inspiring thousands and living my God-given purpose. God is the greatest. Best believe. 

To you reading this, I want you to know anything is possible. Never stop fighting and working for the life of your dreams. 🤍

Bet on yourself + trust God = the WINNING formula.

Wishing you a 2024 that brings you joy and fulfillment. May all your dreams come true.
